DATKit.utils package

Submodules

DATKit.utils.image_utils module

DATKit.utils.image_utils.convert_svg_to_png(svg_path)[source]

Converts an SVG file to PNG using cairosvg.

Parameters:

svg_path (str) – Path to the SVG file.

Returns:

png_path – Path to the generated PNG file.

Return type:

str

DATKit.utils.interpolation_utils module

DATKit.utils.interpolation_utils.nearest(kDa, values, **kwargs)[source]

Create a function for extrapolation that assigns the nearest available value from the input data.

Parameters:

  • kDa (array-like) – Array of known kDa values from the original dataset.

  • values (array-like) – Array of corresponding values to the kDa values.

  • **kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments (not used, included for compatibility).

Returns:

A function that takes an array x as input and returns an array of values corresponding to the nearest kDa value for each point in x.

Return type:

callable

Notes

  • The function uses the absolute difference between each value in x and the known kDa values to determine the nearest value.

  • If x contains values outside the range of kDa, the nearest edge value in kDa will be assigned.

DATKit.utils.interpolation_utils.zeros(*args, **kwargs)[source]

Create a function for extrapolation that assigns a value of zero outside the range.

Parameters:

  • *args (tuple) – Additional positional arguments (not used, included for compatibility).

  • **kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments (not used, included for compatibility).

Returns:

A function that takes an array x as input and returns an array of zeros with the same shape as x.

Return type:

callable

DATKit.utils.metric_utils module

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.datkit_pearsonr(v1, v2)[source]

Computes a distance based on Pearson correlation.

Parameters:

  • v1 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input time series.

Returns:

Distance metric defined as 1 - |Pearson correlation|.

Return type:

float

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.datkit_sliding_window_similarity_derivative_weighted_distance(v1, v2, window_size, step_size, metric, method='mean', t=None)[source]

Computes a weighted similarity between two signals, where the weights are derived from the magnitude of their first derivatives.

Parameters:

  • v1 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • t (array-like) – Time axis.

  • window_size (int) – Sliding window size.

  • step_size (int) – Step size for sliding the window.

  • metric (callable) – Correlation function (e.g., spearmanr, pearsonr).

  • method (str) – Weight computation method: ‘mean’, ‘product’, ‘geometric’, ‘min’, or ‘max’.

Returns:

Weighted similarity score.

Return type:

float

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.datkit_sliding_window_similarity_mean(v1, v2, window_size, step_size, metric, t=None)[source]

Computes the mean of sliding window similarities.

Parameters:

  • v1 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • t (array-like) – Time axis.

  • window_size (int) – Size of the window.

  • step_size (int) – Step between windows.

  • metric (callable) – Similarity function.

Returns:

Mean similarity value. (Missing in current implementation)

Return type:

float

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.datkit_spearmanr(v1, v2)[source]

Computes a distance based on Spearman correlation.

Parameters:

  • v1 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input time series.

Returns:

Distance metric defined as 1 - |Spearman correlation|.

Return type:

float

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.datkit_wasserstein(v1, v2, height=0.1, distance=10, prominence=1)[source]

Computes the Wasserstein (Earth Mover’s) distance between the peaks of two signals.

Parameters:

  • v1 (array-like) – Input signals.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input signals.

  • height (float) – Minimum height of peaks to detect.

  • distance (int) – Minimum horizontal distance between neighboring peaks.

  • prominence (float) – Required prominence of peaks.

Returns:

Wasserstein distance between the positions of detected peaks in v1 and v2.

Return type:

float

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.sliding_window_similarity(v1, v2, window_size, step_size, metric=scipy.stats.spearmanr, t=None)[source]

Computes local similarity between two signals using a sliding window.

Parameters:

  • v1 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • t (array-like) – Time axis corresponding to the signals.

  • window_size (int) – Size of the sliding window (number of samples).

  • step_size (int) – Step size for moving the window.

  • metric (callable) – Similarity function returning a correlation and a p-value (e.g., spearmanr, pearsonr).

Returns:

  • positions (ndarray) – Central time points for each window.

  • similarities (ndarray) – Similarity values computed for each window.

DATKit.utils.metric_utils.weighted_similarity_from_two_derivatives(positions, similarities, v1, v2, window_size, method='mean', t=None)[source]

Computes a weighted similarity score using the absolute first derivative of two signals.

Parameters:

  • positions (array-like) – Time points corresponding to the center of each similarity window.

  • similarities (array-like) – Similarity values for each window.

  • v1 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • v2 (array-like) – Input time series.

  • t (array-like) – Time axis.

  • window_size (int) – Size of the window to use around each position for computing derivatives.

  • method (str) – Weighting method: ‘mean’, ‘product’, ‘geometric’, ‘min’, or ‘max’.

Returns:

  • weights (ndarray) – Weight values computed from signal derivatives.

  • weighted_mean (float) – Weighted mean of similarity values using the computed weights.
